column6: In 2004 energy regulation was placed on hold due to various regulatory orders.
In 2003 Bill 1114 was signed to reverse energy deregulation laws.
*California’s electric choice works on a very limited lottery system called DirectAcccess.
Colorado is Natural Gas Deregulated, however no utilities currently offer choice programs.
*Gas choice is partial and very limited.
Approximately 75% of the state of Illinois is eligible for Natural Gas Choice.
Natural Gas Choice is only available for NIPSCO customers.
*Natural Gas Choice is only available to a small number of consumers.
*Natural Gas Choice underwent more of a ‘restructuring’ process. It is only available to Industrial and Commercial consumers.
*Some residential, commercial and industrial customers in some areas of Maryland are not eligible for Natural Gas Choice.
Nevada is currently campaigning to adopt energy deregulation. The status of this state could change in the near future.
*New Hampshire does not offer Natural Gas Choice to residential customers at this time.
Natural Gas Choice is available however, participation is very limited.
In 2001 Senate Bill 440 was signed for further investigation and study of the impacts of energy deregulation.
Electricity deregulation is available to 85% of Texans.  *Gas choice is available to commercial customers who consumer 3,650 MCF/annually.
Both Natural Gas and Electric Choice programs are limited for residential consumers.
Natural Gas Choice is available but participation is very limited.
*Wisconsin’s Natural Gas Choice program was discontinued in 2001.
*Very limited program, only one utility offers a choice program.
